edu.hpu.epier.sound

Class Main

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.hpu.epier.sound.Main

  • public class Main
extends java.lang.Object
    A class that holds a bunch of static methods to demonstrate the Java sound API. All of these methods are a bit sloppy with their error handling and just throw any exception.
    Author:
    E. Pier

    • Method Detail

      • listAudioDevices

        public static void listAudioDevices()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Lists the input (target) an output (source) data lines available on your system. These are essentially microphones and speakers.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • getInput

        public static javax.sound.sampled.TargetDataLine getInput(int index)
                                                   throws java.lang.Exception
        A utility for getting a particular input (target) line. In a fully developed application you should present a menu to the user so they can choose a different input. For simple demonstration applications like these it is enough to just pick a more or less arbitrary one, as long as there is the ability to pick a different one, if the first one doesn't work.
        Parameters:
        index - The arbitrary index of the line, counting from zero.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if there is no line for that index.
        java.lang.Exception

      • getOutput

        public static javax.sound.sampled.SourceDataLine getOutput(int index)
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        A utility for getting a particular output (source) line. In a fully developed application you should present a menu to the user so they can choose a different input. For simple demonstration applications like these it is enough to just pick a more or less arbitrary one, as long as there is the ability to pick a different one, if the first one doesn't work.
        Parameters:
        index - The arbitrary index of the line, counting from zero.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if there is no line for that index.
        java.lang.Exception

      • createCDQualityFormat

        public static javax.sound.sampled.AudioFormat createCDQualityFormat()
        Creates an AudioFormat that represents "CD quality" sound. The sample rate is sufficient to encode the full frequency response of the human ear, sampes are 16 bit signed integers (i.e. Java shorts), and we have chosen big endian byte order, because that is what Java uses internally. The encoding is "Linear PCM", which means the samples are proportional to the actual signal. "PCM" stands for "Pulse Code Modulated". We have chosen mono, single channel, sound because it is simpler for the sake of demonstration.

      • readFromMicrophone

        public static void readFromMicrophone()
                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Demonstrates reading sound from your sound card. This method displays the wave form to the terminal in a cheap sort of ASCII art display. It runs forever until you kill it.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • playSineWave

        public static void playSineWave()
                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Demonstrates sending data to your sound card, i.e. playing a sound. We create our own sound wave. It plays at full volume, so turn down your speaker volme before running this.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • listSupportedFileFormats

        public static void listSupportedFileFormats()
        Prints the different audio file formats supported by your system. By default Java only supports a few uncompressed formats, the most common of which is .wav files. You can find sample wav files on the internet, or you can google up a way to convert your .mp3 or other format files. Java has a "service provider interface" that lets you add support for other formats. Google "java sound mp3 spi" for some possible options.

      • readAudioFile

        public static void readAudioFile()
                          throws java.lang.Exception
        Reads data from an audio file and plays it to your sound card.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
